conclusion: Shadows are cast when an object blocks light, appearing on the side away from the light source. The length and position of a shadow depend on the position and height of the light source.
Shadows A, B, C, and D are cast behind the objects in the image, indicating the light source is in front of them.
When the light source moves forward, it gets closer to the objects.
As the light moves forward, shadows will shift closer to the objects because the light rays will intersect the ground at a steeper angle.
The closer the light is to the objects, the larger the shadows become due to the divergence of light rays.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to the objects and become larger.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D will move closer to the objects and become larger.
